Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery light chalice; creamy white slip; interior: glazed streaky black; fishbone pattern in added white between white and added red bands; exterior: painted decoration consisting of part of chiton with yellow lines and red and black himation with white crosses and black dots on paryphe.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as London UCL 397 and possibly belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.493.b. Lemos describes this sherd as belonging to the Aphaia Group. The painter and the group are named after the chalice found in the sanctuary of Aphaia at Aegina and vessels from this group display a thematic unity. All the vessels describe figures in garments and in particular, the lower parts of chitons and himatia. None of the vessels in this group have any filling ornament and the interior decoration of some of the vessels consists of komasts rendered in the light on dark technique. A number of Chian chalices from Emporio (Lemos no. 1468) and Rizari (Lemos no, 1487) depict komast dancers alongside female figures dressed in long chitons and playing the double flute and tambourine (or possibly holding a wreath). Occasionally, the female figure is holding a pomegranate. On some chalices, the female figures are incised whilst on others, they are depicted in outline. The figures on the sherds from Naukratis are likely to be from similar scenes interpreted as dancers following and performing with a chorus of women.
1888,0601.493d - not joining - presents the upper part of such a figure.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 111, p. 274, no. 719, pl. II, pl. 94)
Price 1924 / Pottery of Naukratis (pl. VI, no. 8)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0743) (phase 2)
Williams 1983 / Sophilos in the British Museum (p. 170)
